title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 12 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Chronicles chapter 12 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 12 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Chronicles Chapter 12.

questions.question: What did Rehoboam do after establishing and strengthening the kingdom?
options: He forsook the law of the LORD
He built many temples
He made peace with Jeroboam
He sent gifts to Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: He forsook the law of the LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:1 states that Rehoboam forsook the law of the LORD after establishing the kingdom.

questions.question: In the fifth year of Rehoboam, who came up against Jerusalem?
options: Shishak king of Egypt
Jeroboam king of Israel
Pharaoh king of Egypt
Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Shishak king of Egypt
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:2 tells us that Shishak king of Egypt came against Jerusalem in the fifth year of Rehoboam.

questions.question: How many chariots did Shishak bring when he came against Jerusalem?
options: Twelve hundred
One hundred
Five hundred
Two thousand
questions.correctAnswer: Twelve hundred
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:3 specifies that Shishak had twelve hundred chariots.

questions.question: Who came to Rehoboam and the princes of Judah to deliver the LORD's message during Shishak's invasion?
options: Shemaiah the prophet
Iddo the seer
Jeremiah the prophet
Nathan the prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Shemaiah the prophet
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:5 mentions that Shemaiah the prophet came to Rehoboam and the princes with God's message.

questions.question: What was the reason given for Shishak's attack on Jerusalem?
options: Because they had transgressed against the LORD
Because they refused to pay tribute
Because they allied with Babylon
Because they built idols
questions.correctAnswer: Because they had transgressed against the LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:2 states that Shishak came against Jerusalem because they had transgressed against the LORD.

questions.question: What did the princes of Israel and the king do when they heard the prophet's message?
options: They humbled themselves
They went to war immediately
They ignored the message
They sent gifts to Shishak
questions.correctAnswer: They humbled themselves
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:6 describes that the princes and the king humbled themselves before the LORD.

questions.question: What did the LORD decide to do after seeing that they humbled themselves?
options: He would not destroy them but grant some deliverance
He would completely destroy Jerusalem
He would remove Rehoboam from the throne
He would send another enemy against them
questions.correctAnswer: He would not destroy them but grant some deliverance
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:7 states that because they humbled themselves, God would not destroy them but would grant some deliverance.

questions.question: What did Shishak take away from Jerusalem according to the chapter?
options: Treasures of the house of the LORD and the king's house
Only the king's treasures
Only the shields of gold
Nothing was taken
questions.correctAnswer: Treasures of the house of the LORD and the king's house
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:9 records that Shishak took away treasures from both the house of the LORD and the king's house.

questions.question: What did king Rehoboam make to replace the shields of gold taken by Shishak?
options: Shields of brass
Shields of silver
Shields of iron
No replacement shields
questions.correctAnswer: Shields of brass
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:10 tells us that Rehoboam made shields of brass to replace the gold shields.

questions.question: Where was Rehoboam buried after he died?
options: In the city of David
In the temple of the LORD
In Egypt
In Samaria
questions.correctAnswer: In the city of David
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:16 states that Rehoboam was buried in the city of David.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Chronicles 12:14, Rehoboam did evil because he prepared his heart to seek the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:14 says he did evil because he did not prepare his heart to seek the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD's wrath was poured out on Jerusalem by the hand of Shishak.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:7 clarifies that because they humbled themselves, God's wrath was not poured out on Jerusalem by Shishak.

questions.question: True or False: The people who came with Shishak included the Lubims, the Sukkiims, and the Ethiopians.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:3 lists the Lubims, the Sukkiims, and the Ethiopians among those who came with Shishak out of Egypt.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 2 Chronicles 12:8: 'Nevertheless they shall be his _______; that they may know my service, and the service of the kingdoms of the countries.'
options: servants
enemies
friends
allies
questions.correctAnswer: servants
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:8 says they shall be his servants to learn about God's service and that of other kingdoms.

questions.question: Who reigned in Rehoboam's place after he died?
options: Abijah his son
Jeroboam
Shemaiah the prophet
Iddo the seer
questions.correctAnswer: Abijah his son
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:16 states that Abijah, Rehoboam's son, reigned after him.

medium.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 12 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Chronicles Chapter 12 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride and turning away from God after gaining success. Based on 2 Chronicles 12, what biblical truth would you share about humility and its effects?
options: Humbling oneself leads to God's mercy and protection
Ignoring God leads to immediate destruction
Success guarantees God's favor without humility
God does not respond to prayers of humility
questions.correctAnswer: Humbling oneself leads to God's mercy and protection
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:6-7 and 12 show that when Rehoboam and the princes humbled themselves, God chose not to destroy them and turned His wrath away. Humility brings God's mercy and deliverance.

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 12 teach us about the consequences of forsaking God's law in leadership?
options: Forsaking God's law leads to hardship and invasions
Forsaking God's law brings immediate wealth
It has no effect on the kingdom's stability
God always protects leaders regardless of their actions
questions.correctAnswer: Forsaking God's law leads to hardship and invasions
questions.explanation: Verse 1 and 2 explain that Rehoboam forsook the law of the LORD, which led to Shishak king of Egypt attacking Jerusalem, showing the consequences of disobedience in leadership.

questions.question: A believer is worried about facing trials due to their past mistakes. According to 2 Chronicles 12, what hope can you offer regarding God's response to repentance?
options: God will not destroy but grant deliverance upon humility
God will punish without exception
Repentance has no effect on God's judgment
Trials are permanent and unchangeable
questions.correctAnswer: God will not destroy but grant deliverance upon humility
questions.explanation: Verses 7 and 12 show that when Rehoboam humbled himself, God withheld full destruction and allowed some deliverance and peace in Judah.

questions.question: What does 2 Chronicles 12 teach about the importance of obedience to God in family leadership?
options: A leader who does evil and does not seek the LORD harms his family and kingdom
Family leadership is unrelated to spiritual obedience
Leaders should focus only on political power
Spiritual obedience is optional for family leaders
questions.correctAnswer: A leader who does evil and does not seek the LORD harms his family and kingdom
questions.explanation: Verse 14 reveals Rehoboam did evil because he did not prepare his heart to seek the LORD, implying the importance of spiritual devotion in leadership affecting family and nation.

questions.question: How does this passage instruct believers about trusting God's sovereignty during adversity?
options: God allows adversities but can limit their impact when people humble themselves
Adversities always mean God has abandoned His people
Believers should avoid all hardships at any cost
God’s sovereignty means no human action affects outcomes
questions.correctAnswer: God allows adversities but can limit their impact when people humble themselves
questions.explanation: Verses 5-8 show that although God allowed Shishak to come against Jerusalem because of sin, He limited destruction when the king and princes humbled themselves.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with the temptation to ignore God after experiencing success. What practical lesson about faithfulness does 2 Chronicles 12 offer?
options: Faithfulness to God must continue even after success to avoid downfall
Success is a sign that God no longer requires obedience
Ignoring God after success has no consequences
Faithfulness is only necessary in hard times
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to God must continue even after success to avoid downfall
questions.explanation: Verse 1 states Rehoboam forsook the law after establishing his kingdom, leading Israel to sin and suffer consequences, teaching ongoing faithfulness is essential.

questions.question: What does 2 Chronicles 12 reveal about stewardship of spiritual and material blessings?
options: Misuse or disobedience leads to loss of blessings and treasures
Blessings are guaranteed regardless of how they are used
Material blessings are unrelated to spiritual obedience
Stewardship is only about money, not spiritual faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Misuse or disobedience leads to loss of blessings and treasures
questions.explanation: Verses 9-10 show Shishak took away the treasures from the temple and king's house because of disobedience, indicating the importance of faithful stewardship.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Chronicles 12, the LORD completely destroyed Jerusalem by the hand of Shishak.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states God did not destroy Jerusalem because the king and princes humbled themselves, showing partial deliverance instead of complete destruction.

questions.question: True or False: The chapter teaches that seeking God’s guidance after failure can restore peace and stability.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 6-7 and 12 show that after humility and seeking God, the wrath was turned away and things went well in Judah, emphasizing restoration through repentance.

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 12 illustrate the importance of prophetic warnings in spiritual life?
options: Prophets serve as God’s messengers calling to repentance and humility
Prophets only bring messages of judgment without hope
Warnings from prophets should be disregarded
Prophetic words are optional and not important
questions.correctAnswer: Prophets serve as God’s messengers calling to repentance and humility
questions.explanation: Verse 5 shows Shemaiah the prophet delivering God’s message to Rehoboam and the princes, warning them of consequences and calling to humility.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged because of repeated failures in serving God. What encouragement about perseverance does 2 Chronicles 12 offer?
options: God responds to humility and repentance even after failure
Failure means God has permanently rejected you
Perseverance is futile if you have sinned
God’s favor cannot be restored after disobedience
questions.correctAnswer: God responds to humility and repentance even after failure
questions.explanation: Verses 6-7 and 12 show that despite Rehoboam’s sins, when he humbled himself, God withheld destruction and allowed peace, encouraging ongoing repentance and perseverance.

questions.question: How does this passage guide believers in maintaining integrity in their work and leadership?
options: Leaders must prepare their hearts to seek the LORD to avoid evil
Integrity is not important in leadership
Leadership is about power, not obedience
Work ethic is unrelated to spiritual life
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must prepare their hearts to seek the LORD to avoid evil
questions.explanation: Verse 14 states Rehoboam did evil because he did not prepare his heart to seek the LORD, highlighting the need for spiritual integrity in leadership.

questions.question: How can 2 Chronicles 12 teach about being content and grateful during trials?
options: Even after judgment, God can bring peace and success when humbled
Trials mean we should lose hope
Gratitude is irrelevant during hardship
Contentment comes from avoiding all difficulties
questions.correctAnswer: Even after judgment, God can bring peace and success when humbled
questions.explanation: Verse 12 shows that when Rehoboam humbled himself, the LORD's wrath turned away and things went well in Judah, teaching the value of contentment and gratitude amid trials.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Rehoboam was __ years old when he began to reign, and he reigned __ years in Jerusalem.
options: forty-one; seventeen
thirty; twenty
fifty; ten
thirty-five; fifteen
questions.correctAnswer: forty-one; seventeen
questions.explanation: Verse 13 clearly states Rehoboam was forty-one years old when he began to reign, and he reigned seventeen years in Jerusalem.

questions.question: What lesson about spiritual discipline and devotion is drawn from Rehoboam’s failure in 2 Chronicles 12?
options: Neglecting to seek the LORD leads to evil and downfall
Spiritual discipline is unnecessary for kings
Devotion to God can be replaced by political strength
Seeking God is only for common people, not rulers
questions.correctAnswer: Neglecting to seek the LORD leads to evil and downfall
questions.explanation: Verse 14 shows Rehoboam did evil because he did not prepare his heart to seek the LORD, teaching the importance of spiritual discipline for all.

hard.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 12 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Chronicles Chapter 12.

questions.question: What was the primary reason for Shishak king of Egypt coming up against Jerusalem during Rehoboam's reign?
options: Because they had transgressed against the LORD
To establish a trade alliance
To help Rehoboam strengthen his kingdom
To capture the city of David for himself
questions.correctAnswer: Because they had transgressed against the LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:2 states that Shishak came up against Jerusalem because they had transgressed against the LORD.

questions.question: Which groups accompanied Shishak when he attacked Jerusalem?
options: The Lubims, the Sukkiims, and the Ethiopians
The Babylonians, the Moabites, and the Philistines
The Assyrians, the Hittites, and the Canaanites
The Amalekites, the Edomites, and the Ammonites
questions.correctAnswer: The Lubims, the Sukkiims, and the Ethiopians
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:3 mentions these specific groups as part of Shishak’s forces.

questions.question: Who came to Rehoboam and the princes of Judah to deliver God's message during Shishak's invasion?
options: Shemaiah the prophet
Iddo the seer
Nathan the prophet
Ahijah the Shilonite
questions.correctAnswer: Shemaiah the prophet
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:5 identifies Shemaiah as the prophet who came with God's message.

questions.question: What was the divine reason given for allowing Shishak to invade Jerusalem?
options: Because Rehoboam and Israel forsook the LORD
Because Shishak sought revenge for a past conflict
Because Jerusalem refused to pay tribute
Because of a drought and famine
questions.correctAnswer: Because Rehoboam and Israel forsook the LORD
questions.explanation: According to 2 Chronicles 12:1 and 12:5, the invasion was a consequence of forsaking the LORD’s law.

questions.question: What was the response of the king and princes of Judah when confronted with their sin and the invasion?
options: They humbled themselves and acknowledged the LORD's righteousness
They rebelled and sought alliances with Egypt
They ignored the prophet and fortified the city
They sacrificed to foreign gods to gain favor
questions.correctAnswer: They humbled themselves and acknowledged the LORD's righteousness
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:6 states that the princes and king humbled themselves and declared the LORD righteous.

questions.question: What was God's response to the humility of Rehoboam and the princes?
options: He decided not to destroy them but granted some deliverance
He intensified the punishment and destruction
He sent a plague upon Jerusalem
He removed the kingdom from Rehoboam immediately
questions.correctAnswer: He decided not to destroy them but granted some deliverance
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:7 explains that because they humbled themselves, God withheld full destruction.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'they shall be his servants' in verse 8 imply in the historical and theological context?
options: They would be subjugated by Egypt to learn about servitude and foreign kingdoms
They would become allies and share power with Egypt
They would overthrow Egypt after learning their ways
They would gain independence through military strength
questions.correctAnswer: They would be subjugated by Egypt to learn about servitude and foreign kingdoms
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:8 reflects the theme of divine discipline through servitude to foreign powers.

questions.question: What significant items did Shishak take from Jerusalem as spoils?
options: The treasures of the house of the LORD and the king’s house, including gold shields
The Ark of the Covenant and the bronze altar
The sacred scrolls and the temple pillars
The priests’ garments and the city gates
questions.correctAnswer: The treasures of the house of the LORD and the king’s house, including gold shields
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:9 records Shishak’s plundering of temple and royal treasures, including Solomon’s gold shields.

questions.question: What did Rehoboam do in response to the loss of the gold shields made by Solomon?
options: He made shields of brass and placed them with the chief guard
He stopped using shields altogether
He ordered new gold shields to be made
He sought help from other kingdoms to replace the shields
questions.correctAnswer: He made shields of brass and placed them with the chief guard
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:10 describes Rehoboam’s replacement of gold shields with brass ones.

questions.question: How does the replacement of gold shields with brass shields symbolize the consequences of Rehoboam’s actions?
options: It symbolizes a decline in glory and divine favor due to unfaithfulness
It symbolizes increased military strength and resilience
It symbolizes a new covenant with Egypt
It symbolizes the transition from monarchy to priesthood
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes a decline in glory and divine favor due to unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: The gold shields represented former splendor under Solomon, now replaced by inferior brass due to Rehoboam’s sins (2 Chronicles 12:9-10).

questions.question: What does the phrase 'he humbled himself' in verse 12 indicate about Rehoboam's spiritual condition?
options: He repented and turned back to God, averting total destruction
He continued in rebellion against God
He sought alliances with foreign gods
He fled Jerusalem to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: He repented and turned back to God, averting total destruction
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:12 shows that humility before God led to the LORD turning away wrath from Rehoboam.

questions.question: How long did Rehoboam reign in Jerusalem, and what is the significance of the city mentioned?
options: Seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city chosen by the LORD to put His name
Twenty-five years in Hebron, the original capital of Judah
Ten years in Samaria, the capital of Israel
Fifteen years in Bethel, a center of worship
questions.correctAnswer: Seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city chosen by the LORD to put His name
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:13 emphasizes Jerusalem as the LORD’s chosen city and Rehoboam's reign there.

questions.question: What statement best summarizes Rehoboam’s spiritual disposition during his reign according to verse 14?
options: He did evil because he did not prepare his heart to seek the LORD
He was devoted to the LORD and led Israel in righteousness
He was neutral and indifferent to spiritual matters
He sought the LORD earnestly but was unsuccessful
questions.correctAnswer: He did evil because he did not prepare his heart to seek the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 14 directly states Rehoboam’s evil conduct came from failing to seek the LORD sincerely.

questions.question: Which prophets recorded the acts and genealogies related to Rehoboam’s reign?
options: Shemaiah the prophet and Iddo the seer
Nathan and Gad the prophets
Elijah and Elisha
Isaiah and Jeremiah
questions.correctAnswer: Shemaiah the prophet and Iddo the seer
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:15 mentions these two as chroniclers of Rehoboam’s deeds and genealogies.

questions.question: True or False: Rehoboam’s reign was marked by continual peace with Jeroboam according to this chapter.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:15 says there were continual wars between Rehoboam and Jeroboam.

theological.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 12 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Chronicles Chapter 12 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary reason for Shishak king of Egypt attacking Jerusalem during Rehoboam's reign?
options: Because they had transgressed against the LORD
To conquer new territory
To form an alliance with Judah
To overthrow Rehoboam
questions.correctAnswer: Because they had transgressed against the LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:2 states that Shishak came against Jerusalem because they had transgressed against the LORD. This reflects the biblical theme that sin leads to judgment (cf. Deuteronomy 28:15-68; Isaiah 1:4; Romans 1:18-32; Hebrews 12:6).

questions.question: According to 2 Chronicles 12, who came to Rehoboam and the princes to deliver God's message about their forsaking Him?
options: Shemaiah the prophet
Iddo the seer
Nathan the prophet
Elijah the prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Shemaiah the prophet
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:5 records that Shemaiah the prophet came to Rehoboam and the princes to declare God's judgment because they forsook Him. This aligns with the biblical pattern of prophets as God's messengers (cf. Amos 3:7; Jeremiah 1:5; Acts 3:22-23; Hebrews 1:1).

questions.question: What was the response of Rehoboam and the princes when they realized their sin and judgment?
options: They humbled themselves
They fought harder against Egypt
They ignored the warning
They sought help from other nations
questions.correctAnswer: They humbled themselves
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:6 states that Rehoboam and the princes humbled themselves, acknowledging the LORD's righteousness. Humility before God is a key biblical principle for repentance and restoration (cf. Psalm 34:18; Proverbs 3:34; James 4:6; 1 Peter 5:6).

questions.question: What divine action followed the humility of Rehoboam and the princes according to the text?
options: God withheld destruction and granted some deliverance
God immediately destroyed Jerusalem
God sent a plague upon the people
God removed Shishak from the land
questions.correctAnswer: God withheld destruction and granted some deliverance
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:7 explains that because they humbled themselves, God did not destroy them but granted them some deliverance. This reflects God's attribute of mercy even amid judgment (cf. Exodus 34:6-7; Jonah 3:10; Lamentations 3:22-23; Romans 2:4).

questions.question: What was the purpose of Judah becoming servants to Shishak as stated in 2 Chronicles 12?
options: So that they may know God's service and the service of other kingdoms
To permanently lose their freedom
To gain wealth and favor
To escape God's judgment
questions.correctAnswer: So that they may know God's service and the service of other kingdoms
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:8 states that Judah would be servants to Shishak so they might know God's service and the service of other kingdoms, indicating a disciplinary purpose for their subjugation. This aligns with God's corrective discipline to teach His people (cf. Hebrews 12:5-11; Deuteronomy 8:5; Psalm 119:67; Jeremiah 25:11-12).

questions.question: What items did Shishak take from Jerusalem during his invasion?
options: Treasures of the house of the LORD and the king's house, including the shields of gold
Only food supplies
The people of Jerusalem as captives
The temple scrolls
questions.correctAnswer: Treasures of the house of the LORD and the king's house, including the shields of gold
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:9 records that Shishak took all treasures from the house of the LORD and the king's house, including the shields of gold made by Solomon. This illustrates the reality of consequences for unfaithfulness (cf. 1 Kings 14:25-28; Jeremiah 52:16-23; Ezekiel 7:19; Revelation 18:12).

questions.question: How did Rehoboam respond to the loss of the gold shields taken by Shishak?
options: He made shields of brass and entrusted them to the chief of the guard
He stopped guarding the king's house
He made new shields of gold
He surrendered to Shishak
questions.correctAnswer: He made shields of brass and entrusted them to the chief of the guard
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:10 explains that Rehoboam made shields of brass to replace the gold ones and placed them with the chief of the guard. This act shows human adaptation after loss and the limitation of human solutions apart from full dependence on God (cf. 1 Samuel 17:38-39; 2 Kings 18:16; Psalm 20:7; Isaiah 31:1).

questions.question: What was the significance of Rehoboam humbling himself as recorded in this chapter?
options: The wrath of the LORD turned from him and things went well in Judah
He was immediately restored to full power
He was exiled from Jerusalem
He became a prophet
questions.correctAnswer: The wrath of the LORD turned from him and things went well in Judah
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:12 states that Rehoboam's humility caused the LORD's wrath to turn from him, resulting in prosperity in Judah. This underscores the biblical principle that repentance leads to divine mercy and blessing (cf. 2 Chronicles 7:14; Joel 2:13-14; Jonah 3:10; Psalm 51:17).

questions.question: How long did Rehoboam reign in Jerusalem, and what is significant about the city?
options: Seventeen years; Jerusalem was the city chosen by the LORD to put His name
Twenty years; it was the capital of Egypt
Ten years; it was a neutral city
Thirty years; it was a new city built by Rehoboam
questions.correctAnswer: Seventeen years; Jerusalem was the city chosen by the LORD to put His name
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:13 conveys that Rehoboam reigned seventeen years in Jerusalem, which the LORD chose out of all Israel's tribes to put His name there, highlighting God's covenantal presence (cf. Deuteronomy 12:5-7; 1 Kings 11:36; Psalm 132:13-14; Zechariah 8:3).

questions.question: What is said about Rehoboam's heart and his seeking of the LORD?
options: He did evil because he did not prepare his heart to seek the LORD
He was faithful and sought the LORD diligently
He sought other gods alongside the LORD
He sought only the advice of priests
questions.correctAnswer: He did evil because he did not prepare his heart to seek the LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:14 states that Rehoboam did evil because he did not prepare his heart to seek the LORD. This reflects the biblical truth that true obedience requires deliberate preparation of the heart (cf. Deuteronomy 30:6; Psalm 51:10; Jeremiah 29:13; Matthew 22:37).

questions.question: What does the chapter say about the record of Rehoboam’s acts and the nature of his reign?
options: His acts are written in the book of Shemaiah the prophet and Iddo the seer; wars with Jeroboam were continual
His acts were lost and unknown
His reign was peaceful and prosperous without conflict
He was succeeded by a foreign ruler
questions.correctAnswer: His acts are written in the book of Shemaiah the prophet and Iddo the seer; wars with Jeroboam were continual
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:15 records that Rehoboam’s acts are documented by prophets Shemaiah and Iddo, and that wars between him and Jeroboam were continual, showing the ongoing conflict between the divided kingdoms (cf. 1 Kings 14:30; 2 Kings 3:7; Amos 1:5; Hosea 1:4).

questions.question: Who succeeded Rehoboam as king after his death?
options: Abijah his son
Jeroboam
Solomon
Jehoshaphat
questions.correctAnswer: Abijah his son
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:16 states that after Rehoboam died, his son Abijah reigned in his place, continuing the Davidic line. This succession is part of the messianic covenantal promise through David's descendants (cf. 2 Samuel 7:12-16; Psalm 89:3-4; Luke 1:32-33; Romans 1:3).

questions.question: Which foreign peoples are listed as accompanying Shishak in his invasion of Judah?
options: Lubims, Sukkiims, and Ethiopians
Hittites, Philistines, and Moabites
Babylonians, Assyrians, and Persians
Canaanites, Amorites, and Jebusites
questions.correctAnswer: Lubims, Sukkiims, and Ethiopians
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:3 lists these peoples among those who came with Shishak from Egypt, indicating the diverse coalition in the invasion. This reflects the biblical portrayal of God's sovereignty over nations (cf. Genesis 10; Isaiah 45:1-7; Daniel 2:21; Revelation 17:15).

questions.question: What does the chapter imply about the relationship between forsaking God's law and national consequences?
options: Forsaking the law leads to divine judgment and foreign oppression
Forsaking the law brings immediate blessings
Forsaking the law has no real consequences
Forsaking the law results in increased political alliances
questions.correctAnswer: Forsaking the law leads to divine judgment and foreign oppression
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 12:1-5 shows that when Rehoboam and Israel forsook the LORD's law, it led to Shishak's invasion. This theme is consistent biblically where disobedience results in punishment (cf. Leviticus 26:14-46; Deuteronomy 28; Jeremiah 2:19; Romans 1:18-32).

questions.question: What does 2 Chronicles 12 reveal about God's justice and mercy in the context of Rehoboam's reign?
options: God is righteous and just in judgment but merciful when there is repentance
God ignores human sin and allows everything
God punishes without warning or chance for repentance
God only shows mercy to the righteous regardless of repentance
questions.correctAnswer: God is righteous and just in judgment but merciful when there is repentance
questions.explanation: The chapter shows God's righteous judgment for sin (v.5-6) but also mercy when they humbled themselves (v.7-8, 12). This aligns with biblical teaching on God's justice and mercy (cf. Exodus 34:6-7; Psalm 103:8-12; Micah 7:18-19; Romans 2:4).
